though thousands in all ages have been made to drink

Married Life.-Connubal happiness, is of too fine
| texture to be roughly handled. 1t is delicate
flower which Indifference will chill, and suspicion
blast. 1t isa sensitive plant, which will not even
bear the touch of unkindness. 1t must be waercd
with the showers of tender affection, expanded with
the glow ofattention, and guardedby the impregna-
BILE barrier of unshaken confidence. 1t must be
kept unsullied by the hand of carelessness, unob
scured By seltishness. uncontamnated by neglect
Thus maured, it will bloom with fragrance in eve.
ry season of life, and soften the pillow Of declining
years.

house at Athens, being asked by one who obsers ed
the smallness of the design, why man so eminent
should not have an abode more suitable to his dign
tya lie replied thai he should think himself sutf
GENTLY accommodated if he could see that marrow
habtaon filled with real friends. Such was the
opinion of this great master Of human nature, con
cernins the unfrequency Of such an union of mind.
as might deserve the name of friendship that among

to contain all, who should regard him withtsincer

"A NEW EDITIoN.)
A Hermit so grave, once lived in a cave,
Just like Jackson IN Hermitage cevery;
And while he was there, domestcatrd a Bear,
Just exactly like Jackson did Beverly.
So one hot summer day, to repose down he lay;
AS contracted as ckson did iie
And sat Is un, grown wise, to mind oft the flies
Not unlike the employment OF Beverly.
But one obstinate luut still kept buzzng about,
As fearless as Clay and as jovially-
He was wach'd cnsc by Brlin who doomed him 10 ruin
With avengeance as bitter as Beverly.
When at length the fly chose to perch on his nose,
And like Clay he bore down on him heavily
Says fife, "n,y lad nov I'll have you, by gad"-
twas just quotation from Beverly.
Then he struck with force, 'twoud have knocked down
horse.


Or astonsi'd the author of Waverly;
But dreadfu, disaster! it fell on his master,
Just like the great blow am'dby Beverly.
Now in Cuffie's distress his sole comfort was this
He had punished the fly most severely;
While the blow in its fall never touched him at all,
That was aimed Thy bold Carter Beverly.

Seldom do much harm the friendship Of Beverly

Sill had occasion, in journey OF fifteen hun
dred miles, made this winter, IN the different States,
to see great many oil the imported cattle, which
have been brought to this country. and to examine
the method after which their owners keep them du
ring our rigorous winter months.


The particular satisfaction received from the
inspection of your we-kept and valuable animals,
at Powelton, has induced me to address a letter to
you this subject; i'll which propose 10 offer some
remarks arising from the observations have been
enabled to make, and purely from desire to be use
full to the country.


With very few exceptions, the importations have
consisted OF the avorite breed in Great Britain
:. the improved short-horns.' The exceptions are
Devons, the blood of which is getting generally
spread-a.t few Aderneys and Lancashire. OF Here
fords, which have been considered the rivals OF the
'.improved short-horns." | did not see one. Oi
these the Devons are considered an ancient race of
cattle That the variety is permanentone, Is GER
tain from their particular form, their unvarylng
mahogany colour, and waving, curly skins. Thou
sands of to be throughout this country,
somewhat lighter in coour but bearing all the marks
of this blood, except the yellow colour 0f the muz-
zle; and the ring round the eyes. No person can
give an account when the blood was imported, aud
hence it is to be concluded that 1T brought over
On the first settlement Of this country, and that it
came from The Red Deyons, then generally prevail
ing in England. The Devons are considered in
England smart walkers, and endurers OF fatigue;
qualities which distinguish the red oxen amongst
ourselves


The Herefords are an improved breed, and are
thought to have sprung from the Devons. They
have bald faces with deadish colours, are large and
considered profitable as beef; they make strong OK
en- So much pains has been taken with their bree-
ding, that they may be considered now pure, I'M
proved breed.


The improved short horns also, pure, i'm
proved breed. The individuals resemble each other
so much, that the must expert person can scarce
distinguish them. They the largest OF all the
breeds AS far as their short horns CO. they are to
be considered permanent variety: but the original
short horns, before the improvements touk place
were considered poor breed. The improvements
effected for them what Mr.. Bakewell did Tor the
Dsley sheep, making them perhaps the most pro-
ftabe breed in existence, il justice is doae to them


Many controversies are still carrying on III En-
gland as to the origin of these improvements, which
would not excite much interest here. The appear
aace Of these superb animals at once satisfies judges,
AGHYCULTatRAL
ON THE SHORT HORN AND DEVON CATTLE.

The peach is the most delicious fruit that grows in
this country but the farmer does not rear the tree.
because it ..dies so soon." Experience has taught
me that Peach trees will live and flourish fifteen or
twenty years, if the ground in which they are plan
ted be cultivated but il their enemy, the worm de-
scrbed in the following paragraph. be destroyed
every year. should suppose they will live much
longer Noao is the time for destroying the uorn',
which is easily detected in its ravases the dlrec-
tons of this receipt are pursued.


Peach Trees. This is the season to destroy the
pest which kills this valuable ree just above the sur
face of the earth you will now find gum, which has
issued from the wound which the worm has made III
his ravages on the root, and OF the eatings OF this
gum he has formed sack, in which he has enclosed
HIMSELF about one inch in length and Of a dark
brown colour: looking much like tobacco thrown
away after chewing. This contains an insect just
ready to come forth with wings it is ola beautiful
black. aud looks much like wasp not so long, nor
with the small middle Of that insect but having
around his body ring of bright orange COLOUR
III few days these insects will be at maturity and
they Immediately commence new work OF 'rs'ruc-
tio by depostng near the riot of the tree their nts,
or young, which in time are quckcned and commence
eating again. 1t is supposed that covering which
will prevent their to the root OF the tree, will
preserve it from damage.

.sAnd l." said Castello, "received double that sum

A certain minister, in the overlowngs Of hiszeal,
was preaching to large congregation, and at length
he concluded by prayer. Among other expressions,
he prayed (as his profession usually do oon such oc
cassions, And beseech, thee, with all humanity.
o Lord, to forgive our shortcomings" This ex-
preston was reiterated number Of times, to the
confusion of one of his audience, whose name was
Cummings; and who being remarkably short IN his
person. supposed himself represented, and took the
entire tendency of the passage to himself. On the
breaking up Of the meeting, he appeared greatly
agltated. and catching his friend by the button, in
qured of him eagerly, what the ID his minister
meant by exposing him thus openly before all the
congregation especially as he was so seldom in the
habit Of attending divine worship. His friend en-
deav0red to excuse an remunstrate. ''Oh but
am certain" replied the other, she meant me-for
he kept his eve steadily upon Inc, and pointed at
me throug RI his whole discoutse-ind must have in
tended to insult me personally for he said Il pray
thee Q Lord, to forgive our short Coaaings.


a fact.-Not long since, in South Carolina, a
clergyman was preaching on the disobedence of Jo-
nah, when commanded to go and preach to the Nj
nevites. After decaiming at some length on the
awful consequence Of tisubedience to the Divine
commands he exclaimed in voice of thunder. that
passed throushthe congregation like an electric shock
..and are there any Jonahs hereso There me-
gro present. whose name was Jonah, and thinking
himself called on Immediately rose. and turning up
his white eye TO the preacher, with his broadcast grin
and best bow, very readily answered, "Here be one
1Nassa."

tented with the assurance that the ANIMALS we pos
sess of that breed, spring from the celebrated Oui
Comet sold for Que thousand guneas at MI, Coi-
ling's sale in 1910, and who was bought by Mf.
WetherilI, from whose stock you procured your

Leaving aside the celebrity OF THIS Dreea' wi'c'i
has been the inducement for its importation INTO
this country. the proper inquiry for us is, 'hoa0
zoe ought TO treat ii here: IN order 10 gel tne ".oSs
money out Of ii, IN the shortest period cf ainle.


THIS breed is said to afford greater quantlty OIL
beef taow and milk, than any other. IN tpe same
time. and is remarkable for its early maturity
Sone Of the cows are very deep mixers, and all fair
ones They are entitled to the reputation OF sooo
mixers but it is only now and then that cow glv-
lng from 80 to 40 quarts day is 10 DC uie' w,e'
This propensity to convert all the food into mix IS
sometimes met with in individuals OF other breeds.


The property of being very deep mixers. therefore,
is to be considered accidental, rather than enc
| which can be continued with any certainty IN me
breed.--Take one short-h0rn with another no pfeeu
is more valuable for its milk. or keeps IN peter con-
dition, under the same circumstance, OF Soes 10
beef at less expence, or furnishes more money ana
manure in given time. In order to keep up these
great Qualities we must remember, that IN their iia-
tive country, it is considered indispensable to Keep
them extremely well, aud in very different manner


from the general custom prevailing here; wnlch ls.


in summer, to leave cattle to help themselves 10


what they can find even in the most severe drought.


and in winter; to give them moderate quantity OF


hay and straw. In England, where they are less
/ troubled with dry weather than we are. tney nave


always green crops and roots to give 10 the'' anu


they Give them in abundance. 1t is there consider


ed the higher this sort of keep the better the health


of the COW. the richer her milk. the stronger her


calf, and the greater the quantity aud value OF the


dung. If all this provldent attention be necessary
/ in that moist climate. it is certain that the breed


will degenerate with u.s. if it is not Kept III high con-


diton. Hot climates produce shallow mixers;


and where exceptions occur they yet poor very fase


when indifferenty kept and II becomes more eXPen-


sive to recover their condition than to keep up,


The wear and tear Of condition III deep mixers, IS


very great. and is only to be checked by abundance
of succulent food and roots where they are not


to be had bv occasional feeds Of meal with their hay


A writer in the n. L. Farmer recommends the


substitution of Mulberry Hedges in the places of the
: walls and fences commonly used in this country Tor


the division of fields. he tree is well calculates,


for the purpose being easily cultivated, OF thick


growth and Of such nature as to bear clipping and


cutting without injury. The leaves of course might


be proiitably applied to the feeding OF silk worms,


the raising of which on an extensive scale asHbeen
auain recommended to the attention OF farmers.


The plants should be set into the ground about one
foot apart and they should be clipped SO as not to
exceed five feet in height. and IL inches IN thick


ness Let a farmer compare the annual expense or
taking care Of such hedge, with that OF keeping in
repair wooden fence, and he can easily ascertain
, whether change would be profitable.


A gentleman of Lauderda'e county, Alabama.
i made, the last season, considerable quantity OF
! Wine from the Muscadue, or Muscadne Grape,


which he saws resembles. in flavor and in coor the
best Madeira wine. and which, lie believes, only
. wants aye to reuderit as fine as any wine he ever
drank Muscadines grow ndlgenoasiy, pretty pleii-
teousy and near the banks OF most OF the rivers
!. and creeks. of Nurth Carolina aud it might be
g worth the while of some Of our enterprisng citizens,
# to make an experiment in manufacturing a wine
# from, them such vast quantities OF which are lmpor.
: ted fro,n abroad, and consumed among US. II we
o pretend to render ourselves independents OF tpresn
i. nations let us not stop half way-but manufacture
). our drink. as well as our food and raiment.

horse.


Or astonsi'd the author of Waverly;

The Herefords are an improved breed, and are
thought to have sprung from the Devons. They
have bald faces with deadish colours, are large and
considered profitable as beef; they make strong OK
en- So much pains has been taken with their bree-
ding, that they may be considered now pure, I'M
proved breed.


The improved short horns also, pure, i'm
proved breed. The individuals resemble each other
so much, that the must expert person can scarce
distinguish them. They the largest OF all the
breeds AS far as their short horns CO. they are to
be considered permanent variety: but the original
short horns, before the improvements touk place
were considered poor breed. The improvements
effected for them what Mr.. Bakewell did Tor the
Dsley sheep, making them perhaps the most pro-
ftabe breed in existence, il justice is doae to them


Many controversies are still carrying on III En-
gland as to the origin of these improvements, which
would not excite much interest here. The appear
aace Of these superb animals at once satisfies judges,

full articles.article:
The peach is the most delicious fruit that grows in
this country but the farmer does not rear the tree.
because it ..dies so soon." Experience has taught
me that Peach trees will live and flourish fifteen or
twenty years, if the ground in which they are plan
ted be cultivated but il their enemy, the worm de-
scrbed in the following paragraph. be destroyed
every year. should suppose they will live much
longer Noao is the time for destroying the uorn',
which is easily detected in its ravases the dlrec-
tons of this receipt are pursued.


Peach Trees. This is the season to destroy the
pest which kills this valuable ree just above the sur
face of the earth you will now find gum, which has
issued from the wound which the worm has made III
his ravages on the root, and OF the eatings OF this
gum he has formed sack, in which he has enclosed
HIMSELF about one inch in length and Of a dark
brown colour: looking much like tobacco thrown
away after chewing. This contains an insect just
ready to come forth with wings it is ola beautiful
black. aud looks much like wasp not so long, nor
with the small middle Of that insect but having
around his body ring of bright orange COLOUR
III few days these insects will be at maturity and
they Immediately commence new work OF 'rs'ruc-
tio by depostng near the riot of the tree their nts,
or young, which in time are quckcned and commence
eating again. 1t is supposed that covering which
will prevent their to the root OF the tree, will
preserve it from damage.

ny years, during which time he every day drank her

A young pert, prating lawyer, one day boasted to
the facetous Castelu that he had received five and
twenty guneas for speaking in certain cause.
.sAnd l." said Castello, "received double that sum
for holding my tongue"


A certain minister, in the overlowngs Of hiszeal,
was preaching to large congregation, and at length
he concluded by prayer. Among other expressions,
he prayed (as his profession usually do oon such oc
cassions, And beseech, thee, with all humanity.
o Lord, to forgive our shortcomings" This ex-
preston was reiterated number Of times, to the
confusion of one of his audience, whose name was
Cummings; and who being remarkably short IN his
person. supposed himself represented, and took the
entire tendency of the passage to himself. On the
breaking up Of the meeting, he appeared greatly
agltated. and catching his friend by the button, in
qured of him eagerly, what the ID his minister
meant by exposing him thus openly before all the
congregation especially as he was so seldom in the
habit Of attending divine worship. His friend en-
deav0red to excuse an remunstrate. ''Oh but
am certain" replied the other, she meant me-for
he kept his eve steadily upon Inc, and pointed at
me throug RI his whole discoutse-ind must have in
tended to insult me personally for he said Il pray
thee Q Lord, to forgive our short Coaaings.


a fact.-Not long since, in South Carolina, a
clergyman was preaching on the disobedence of Jo-
nah, when commanded to go and preach to the Nj
nevites. After decaiming at some length on the
awful consequence Of tisubedience to the Divine
commands he exclaimed in voice of thunder. that
passed throushthe congregation like an electric shock
..and are there any Jonahs hereso There me-
gro present. whose name was Jonah, and thinking
himself called on Immediately rose. and turning up
his white eye TO the preacher, with his broadcast grin
and best bow, very readily answered, "Here be one
1Nassa."


Real Military Spirit of the regiments Of
Old Hampshire, as we learn from the Northampton
Post, lately postponed their muster for a gear, on
account of the weather. These fine fellows had ne
notion of spelling their reymentals by marching IN

u having such precedent what officer would not ra


ther keep his epauete and his chapeau brass snuS
in the chest, than run the haZZard Of taking OF
their shine" in the dreary drizzly day, OF of mar
!, ching like a drowned turkey-cock in the pltiles


shower.


Many meditated dues have been preventedby th

asked by Lord Talbot, how many times they wer'

tented with the assurance that the ANIMALS we pos
sess of that breed, spring from the celebrated Oui
Comet sold for Que thousand guneas at MI, Coi-
ling's sale in 1910, and who was bought by Mf.
WetherilI, from whose stock you procured your
lately imported and very beautiful heller. ,,


Leaving aside the celebrity OF THIS Dreea' wi'c'i
has been the inducement for its importation INTO
this country. the proper inquiry for us is, 'hoa0
zoe ought TO treat ii here: IN order 10 gel tne ".oSs
money out Of ii, IN the shortest period cf ainle.


THIS breed is said to afford greater quantlty OIL
beef taow and milk, than any other. IN tpe same
time. and is remarkable for its early maturity
Sone Of the cows are very deep mixers, and all fair
ones They are entitled to the reputation OF sooo
mixers but it is only now and then that cow glv-
lng from 80 to 40 quarts day is 10 DC uie' w,e'
This propensity to convert all the food into mix IS
sometimes met with in individuals OF other breeds.


The property of being very deep mixers. therefore,
is to be considered accidental, rather than enc
| which can be continued with any certainty IN me
breed.--Take one short-h0rn with another no pfeeu
is more valuable for its milk. or keeps IN peter con-
dition, under the same circumstance, OF Soes 10
beef at less expence, or furnishes more money ana
manure in given time. In order to keep up these
great Qualities we must remember, that IN their iia-
tive country, it is considered indispensable to Keep
them extremely well, aud in very different manner


from the general custom prevailing here; wnlch ls.


in summer, to leave cattle to help themselves 10


what they can find even in the most severe drought.


and in winter; to give them moderate quantity OF


hay and straw. In England, where they are less
/ troubled with dry weather than we are. tney nave


always green crops and roots to give 10 the'' anu


they Give them in abundance. 1t is there consider


ed the higher this sort of keep the better the health


of the COW. the richer her milk. the stronger her


calf, and the greater the quantity aud value OF the


dung. If all this provldent attention be necessary
/ in that moist climate. it is certain that the breed


will degenerate with u.s. if it is not Kept III high con-


diton. Hot climates produce shallow mixers;


and where exceptions occur they yet poor very fase


when indifferenty kept and II becomes more eXPen-


sive to recover their condition than to keep up,


The wear and tear Of condition III deep mixers, IS


very great. and is only to be checked by abundance
of succulent food and roots where they are not


to be had bv occasional feeds Of meal with their hay


A writer in the n. L. Farmer recommends the


substitution of Mulberry Hedges in the places of the
: walls and fences commonly used in this country Tor


the division of fields. he tree is well calculates,


for the purpose being easily cultivated, OF thick


growth and Of such nature as to bear clipping and


cutting without injury. The leaves of course might


be proiitably applied to the feeding OF silk worms,


the raising of which on an extensive scale asHbeen
auain recommended to the attention OF farmers.


The plants should be set into the ground about one
foot apart and they should be clipped SO as not to
exceed five feet in height. and IL inches IN thick


ness Let a farmer compare the annual expense or
taking care Of such hedge, with that OF keeping in
repair wooden fence, and he can easily ascertain
, whether change would be profitable.


A gentleman of Lauderda'e county, Alabama.
i made, the last season, considerable quantity OF
! Wine from the Muscadue, or Muscadne Grape,


which he saws resembles. in flavor and in coor the
best Madeira wine. and which, lie believes, only
. wants aye to reuderit as fine as any wine he ever
drank Muscadines grow ndlgenoasiy, pretty pleii-
teousy and near the banks OF most OF the rivers
!. and creeks. of Nurth Carolina aud it might be
g worth the while of some Of our enterprisng citizens,
# to make an experiment in manufacturing a wine
# from, them such vast quantities OF which are lmpor.
: ted fro,n abroad, and consumed among US. II we
o pretend to render ourselves independents OF tpresn
i. nations let us not stop half way-but manufacture
). our drink. as well as our food and raiment.
